greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the sum of primes p for those k's, 2 <= k <= n, where gcd(k,n) = p^j > 1. (a(1) = 0.)
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
example: The integers k, 2 <= k <= 12, where gcd(k,12) is a power of a prime are 2,3,4,8,9 and 10. gcd(2,12) = 2^1, gcd(3,12) = 3^1, gcd(4,12) = 2^2, gcd(8, 12) = 2^2, gcd(9,12) = 3^1 and gcd(10,12) = 2^1. The sum of the prime bases of the prime-powers is 2+3+2+2+3+2 = 14. So a(12) = 14.
mathematica: f[n_] := Plus @@ First /@ Flatten[Select[FactorInteger[GCD[Range[n], n]], Length[ # ] == 1 &], 1]; Table[f[n], {n, 80}] (* _Ray Chandler_, Sep 06 2006 *)
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Sep 02 2006
ext: Corrected and extended by _Ray Chandler_, Sep 06 2006
